message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest postpartum hemorrhage, and the soft uterine fundus and blood clots indicate uterine atony. The next best step would be uterine massage and administration of oxytocin, which will stimulate uterine contractions and help control bleeding. Misoprostol can also be used to control bleeding, but uterine massage and oxytocin are the first line of treatment. Manually removing retained placental fragments and uterine artery embolization are not appropriate for this patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum bleeding and the soft uterine fundus suggests uterine atony. Uterine massage and administration of oxytocin are recommended as the first-line treatment for postpartum bleeding due to uterine atony. Misoprostol can be used as an alternative, but not as the first step. Manually removing placental fragments or performing uterine artery embolization are not indicated at this stage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, and the next step is to perform uterine massage and administer oxytocin, which will help contract the uterus and control bleeding. Misoprostol may be used in addition to uterine massage and oxytocin, but it is not the first-line treatment. Manually removing retained placental fragments and uterine artery embolization are not indicated in this case, as the placenta was delivered spontaneously and intact, and the patient does not have any signs of pelvic trauma or bleeding from a uterine artery injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage and the initial management is to perform uterine massage to stimulate contractions and administer oxytocin to control bleeding. Misoprostol is used for cervical ripening, induction of labor and to prevent postpartum hemorrhage if oxytocin is not available. Manually removing retained placental fragments and uterine artery embolization are more invasive options that are considered if the bleeding persists.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, which is defined as blood loss more than 500mL after a vaginal delivery. The soft uterine fundus indicates uterine atony. The next best step in management would be to perform uterine massage and administer oxytocin to stimulate uterine contractions and reduce bleeding. Misoprostol is used in cases of retained placenta, which is not present in this case. Manually removing retained placental fragments or performing uterine artery embolization may be necessary if bleeding persists despite initial management or if there are other sources of bleeding, but they are not the first line of treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum bleeding, which is common after vaginal delivery. The soft uterine fundus and presence of blood clots suggest uterine atony. The next best step in management would be to perform uterine massage to help promote uterine contractions and administer oxytocin to help control bleeding. Misoprostol is used in cases of retained placenta or postpartum hemorrhage, but there is no indication for this in the scenario presented. Manually removing retained placental fragments or performing uterine artery embolization would not be appropriate for a case of uterine atony.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing postpartum hemorrhage, which can be treated with uterine massage and administration of oxytocin to promote uterine contractions and control bleeding. Misoprostol is used for prophylaxis of postpartum hemorrhage and is not indicated in this case. Manually removing retained placental fragments or performing uterine artery embolization are more invasive measures and not indicated as first-line treatment for this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vaginal bleeding and uterine fundus palpation suggest postpartum hemorrhage. The next step should be to perform uterine massage to promote uterine contraction and administration of oxytocin to increase uterine tone. Misoprostol is used for prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage, but is not the initial step. Manually removing retained placental fragments is only done if there is evidence of retained placenta. Uterine artery embolization is a more invasive treatment option and is typically reserved for cases with persistent bleeding despite conservative measures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The postpartum bleeding and the soft uterine fundus suggest uterine atony. Uterine massage and administration of oxytocin can help stimulate the uterus to contract and control bleeding. Misoprostol can also help, but may take longer to take effect. Manually removing retained placental fragments and uterine artery embolization are not appropriate for this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The vaginal bleeding, soft uterine fundus, and blood clots suggest postpartum hemorrhage. The next best step in management is performing uterine massage and administering oxytocin. Misoprostol is another commonly used medication to prevent postpartum bleeding but is not the best option in this scenario. Manually removing retained placental fragments or performing uterine artery embolization may be necessary in more severe cases of postpartum hemorrhage, but these are not indicated for mild bleeding like in this case.
